led. it is but reasonable to suppose that it will constitute the
principal line of travel to that growing state. And this tide
0f emigration, as it annually pours through our borders, will
materially aid in swelling the profits of the road, developing
the resources of the country, stimulating its enterprise, and
peopling its solitudes, with a busy, thriving, industrious and
enterprising population.
But as I have already said, it is not my intention to discuss
the general advantages of the road. This has already been
done by abler men. And if am not mistaken in the signs
'now before me, in this enthusiastic meeting, and in this numerous concourse of people, there exists no difference of
opinion on this subject. But we have met to confer freely
as to what may be done to accomplish our object, and to ascertain how far the city will co-operate with the country, in
the great enterprise, which is to develop the resources of the
one, and add to the commerce and the opulence of the other.
We of the country, are impatient to open for ourselves, a
railroad communication with the market for our produce.—
We have had other projects in view, which we thought suited
our purposes : bat which were of far less importance than
the one which has called us together. We were ripe to build
a railroad to Berwick's Bay, as suggested by Gov. Mouton ;
or, in the event of receiving no support from our neighbors, we
of St. Landry, felt ourselves prepared, and feel ourselves yet
prepared, to open a railroad communication with Morganza.
on the Mississippi river. We have abandoned these schemes
for the present, and hope and believe that the success of our
new undertaking, will compel us to abandon them forever.—
a he direct road to New Orleans, we prefer to all others. We
believe it to be a work of great public importance ; and feel a
SHOW of state pride, while looking forward to the day, when we
snail be able to point to it, as the first great monument of the
public enterprise of Louisiana. Our friends of New Orleans,
